As we continue with Distance Learning, it is time to finalize a decision on grading practices for the third trimester/fourth quarter. Commissioner of Education Cardona released guidance on grading indicating the determination of grading policies and approaches continues to remain at the local level. I put together a comprehensive grading proposal for the Shelton Public Schools that I believe addresses the needs of all students. I believe this decision should not be a one-size-fits-all approach; rather a hybrid with parent choice. Please review the draft grading proposal located at https://resource.echalk.com/sr/aA0HInc0 that will be discussed at the upcoming April 30 virtual special meeting of the Board of Education. Your feedback can be emailed to me (bsmith@sheltonpublicschools.org) or Board of Education Chairperson Kathy Yolish (kyolish@sheltonpublicschools.org). \n
\n
Thank you in advance for your feedback,
\n

p.strong: Shelton Public Schools Distance Learning Plan 2.0

em.span: “Meeting the needs of our learners with a unique approach and
new ways to deliver effective instruction”

p.span: As in-person classes across the State remain closed, the Shelton Public School system recognizes its responsibilities to meet the unique needs to support the learning of their students during these unprecedented times. As Shelton continues engagement in our distance-learning and strives to meet the educational needs of all students, it is important that the design of the
involve the processes of reflection, adjustments, continuous learning and growth. Based on the feedback received from our community and staff, we have recalibrated our Distance Learning Plan.

The Shelton Distance Learning Plan 2.0 is designed to assist educators in addressing a variety of needs as well as provide guidance based on resources from the CSDE. All K-12 teachers will continue to provide their students learning experiences supported through District standards and curriculum, utilizing the distance learning framework and resources designed from this plan.

p.strong: Distance Learning 2.0 begins on Monday, April 20th.

p.span: All teachers must continue to use Infinite Campus. The Shelton Public Schools has been a Google district for several years. The ability to promote digital learning through your Google classroom is endless. Google Classroom interfaces with Infinite Campus. Here are some resources to support your use of Google:

A Google shared drive for all staff has been created and populated. Please utilize this resource. The Distance Learning shared drive was created for staff to upload any lesson ideas, google slides, videos, etc. to share district-wide across grade-levels and content areas. Please feel free to continue to share or view. Thank you to all the staff who have been sharing resources!

p.strong: Below are various topics relative to effective distance learning:

p.span: Now more than ever differentiated instruction is necessary as our students are learning in isolation. Teachers need to provide assignments that align to their various learning needs. Consider using videos to model directions that are either created by you or other educators that fit the purpose. Do not plan and deliver a “one-size fits all” assignment or send assignments with only written directions.

As a reminder, we recommended to not overload our students and families. It has come to our attention that multiple assignments for a single subject are sent daily. Pace yourselves. Distance Learning is a marathon, not a sprint. We suggest that you provide assignments that students may pace themselves over a few days as opposed to providing long-daily
Just because we are doing distance learning, it does not require everything to be technology based. Try to plan more “tech-free” activities for your students.

li.span: Based on feedback we have received,
it is strongly suggested that assignments be posted on Mondays
so that students may pace themselves throughout the week.

Choice of activities, projects, etc. should be engaging and align to current units in content areas, to the best of your abilities. We will continue to follow district pacing calendars, curriculum and grading expectations.
Provide assignments that students may pace themselves over a few days as opposed to providing long-daily assignments.
Try not to "flood" google classroom or any other platform with documents. This can be overwhelming for students and families- pacing, plan in 2 week intervals.
Long term assignments which require critical thinking and problem solving are best practices.

As a reminder, NEWSELA is a great resource for unified arts and support staff, many already use the resource. NEWSELA has now opened up ALL their products to districts for free during this closure. This means, we now have access to ELA, Science, Social Studies and Social Emotional Learning curriculum units and activities.

p.span: We are continuing with the practice of not allowing groups of students/whole class to be filmed through live streaming during classroom whole group instruction.

li.span: Teachers may still post videos and students may post/send pre-recorded videos.
Communication from students may be done one on one through audio or messaging considering parents are aware and comfortable.

p.span: We are now allowing teachers/staff to conduct one on one live video sessions. Teachers and support staff should

strong.em: begin using Google Meets with students on an individual basis

p.span: , when necessary, on April 20, 2020. This will assist in providing our best effort in meeting students’ IEP goals and objectives and other specialized instruction or support (i.e. differentiation, English Learners).
Please refer to the following links for technology support with Google Meets:

Just as we are practicing, we have been asked by the parents and students if you, as teachers, can limit and/or group your communications within a given day. As families share tech resources at home, some students may be going on-line at one point during the day and may not return later.

li.span: Google Classroom Guardian notification: Teachers have the ability to input Guardian email addresses into their Google Classes, and then parents can choose how they want to be automatically notified - daily or weekly. It’s a built in feature to Google Classroom, you may want to explore.

p.span: The CSDE has provided us with guidelines regarding attendance. Upon review of these documents, we are in compliance and have made the necessary adjustments as needed to be aligned to the State's requirements in attendance. Our priority in attendance will be in ensuring the safety and well-being of all students. We will continue our efforts to focus interventions necessary to students who are not participating and missing check-ins.

li.span: Please continue to follow the established systems of attendance for your school. As has been the practice, when a student has not "checked-in" for attendance for three or more consecutive days, that student must be reported to building administration. Attendance will be taken daily through IC by the homeroom teacher at K-6 and class period attendance in 7-12.
Parents have been asked to email their teachers if their child cannot participate on a given day or days. Those students will be marked as excused.

p.span: The following topics have been developed with direct alignment to
CSDE recommendations, please feel free to access
the state’s additional resources regarding this topics at:

a.span: Resources to Support Continued School Closures Due to COVID-19 Vol. 3 2020

li.span: The Office of Teaching and Learning will be developing distance learning professional learning sessions for staff. More information to follow.
In the meantime, please continue to take the necessary time as needed for personal Professional Learning at home through videos and/or webinars.

p.span: Assessment, especially in this distance-learning period, should measure student progress towards meeting academic standards. It is important for assessment to move towards providing students with

Teachers should continue to give detailed feedback to students on their performance to support learning. Teacher feedback could be communicated through online one on one meetings or web-based applications, and will give students valuable insight into their understanding, guidance on how to improve, and motivation to learn and grow. Research supports the impact of non-graded feedback to focus students on learning rather than performance, and when the psychological and intellectual “load” on students and their families is so significant, it is important to consider leaning on the side of support and learning rather than competition and high-stakes performance.
Please continue to follow established grading practices. Revised grading procedures continue to be discussed and vetted and will be communicated when finalized.

div.p: The Shelton Public Schools, in conjunction with Whitsons Food Service, will be offering bagged breakfast and lunch free of charge for all students 18 and under enrolled in the Shelton Public Schools and Holy Trinity Catholic Academy in Shelton beginning Wednesday, March 18, 2020. Parents may pick up breakfast and lunch for their children beginning Wednesday (and continuing Monday through Friday during school closure) between the hours of 9:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m. in the Shelton High School bus loop. During this time, the high school’s Meadow Street gates will be closed in order to keep the flow of traffic on Meadow Street moving. All participants may enter and exit the high school grounds via the North Constitution Boulevard entrance.
